entry.title: Snorkeling with Data
entry.content:
A system for rapidly creating training sets with weak supervision

As name of the paper suggests “Snorkel: A System for Fast Training Data Creation”, Snorkel is a tool used for rapid creation of training datasets without hand labeling thousands of data points. With the increas in intricacies of state-of-the-art machine learning models, the requirement of large data also becomes a necessity. In todays scenario, labeling training data is increasingly the largest bottleneck in deploying machine learning systems. Snorkel introduces a whole new paradigm of Data Programming, instead of making users handlabel the data, it makes users write labeling function that express arbitrary heuristics, which can have unknown accuracies and correlations, to assign labels to the data. Training set prepared by Snorkel had been proven to be much more effective and has increased predictive performance 45% (on average) and speeded up the process by 2.8x (on average) against the training set obtained by hand labeling the data.

For training standard machine learning model, we usually need a well structured data that are easy to process. But what if we want to extract our training data from a bunch of newspapers, scientific papers, Medical images? This type of data is refereed to as Dark Data. Snorkel is capable of providing us a with well structured labelled data by process called Dark Data Extraction. This gives us a noise aware data that is capable of training high performance predictive model.

Principles of Snorkel’s Design

  • Bring All Sources to Bear: System should enable user to all sources of weak supervision available to create Labeling functions.

  • Training Data as the Interface to ML: The system should model label sources to produce a single, probabilistic label for each data point and train any of a wide range of classifiers to generalize beyond those sources.

  • Supervision as Interactive Programming: The system should provide rapid results in response to user supervision.

The main challenges here are unknown sources to resolve disagreements and pass on the critical lineage information to the end model being trained. Since we don’t have the ground truth here, Snorkel learns the accuracies of weak supervision sources and trains a generative model.

Snorkel Architecture

Workflow of snorkel proceeds in three main stages:

  • Writing Labeling Functions
  • Modeling Accuracies and Correlations
  • Training a Discriminative Model

Here are some terminologies that will be used later:

  • Entity: Concepts that can be separated into meaningful categories
  • Relation: Semantic association between two or more entities
  • Candidate: An object for which we want to make a prediction about
  • Knowledge Base: A repository of structured information

Let’s consider a task of building a knowledge base of married couples by extracting mentions of spouses from news source. We will use Data Programming approach and try to get heuristics based noisy label data.

1. Writing Labeling Functions

First task is to get entities from the given data and there are multiple ways to shortlist entities from the corpus. We can use Spacy’s noun-phrase chunking or can use some existing knowledge base to get entities. We can then pair these entities to get all candidates which will be labeled in following steps, here candidates are pairs of people mentioned in sentences. Now our task is to find if these candidates are spouse of each other or not.

Humans can use real-world knowledge, context and common-sense heuristics to assign a label to candidate. We will use these abilities to write a number of labeling functions. Some of the approaches for Declarative labeling functions are:

  • Pattern Based : Use heuristics and common pattern to write labeling function
  • Distant Supervision: Use any existing knowledge base to label candidates
  • Weak Classifiers: Classifiers that are insufficient for our task and provides us a noisy label.
  • Labeling Function Generator: It’s a inbuilt Snorkel tool which generates multiple labeling functions from a single resource, such as crowd-sourced labels.

Labeling Functions will label candidates as positive(1), negative(-1) or abstain(0) in this case.

Using Pattern Based approach, we can write LFs using following heuristics:

  • Mention of “Husband” and “Wife” in a sentence : 1
  • Mention of “Spouse” in a sentence : 1
  • Surnames of both entities being same : 1
  • Mention of keywords like “Boyfriend”, “Girlfriend”, “Boss” : -1
  • Mention of “are married” keyword : 1

We can also use a knowledge base of famous married people to create a labeling function, for eg. we know “Barack Obama” and “Michelle Obama” are married, so we can directly assign positive label to it.

2. Modeling Accuracies and Correlations

We asses the quality of our labeling functions on following metrics:

  • Accuracy: The percentage of candidates labeling function labels correctly
  • Coverage: The percentage of all candidates that are labeled by more the one LF
  • Conflict: The percentage of candidates with more than one labels that disagree

Ideally, we want high-coverage and high-accuracy LFs but LFs with probability better than random chance will work and improve final result. Having conflicts is actually good because it allows our learn information about the LFs.

Next step to make a Generative Model to unify all weak supervision we have provided. To get an intuition of this, we can assume every LF as a vote and we need to find weighted majority vote. As Condorcet’s Jury Theorem states ‘As long as most people vote correctly, adding more people improves the accuracy of majority vote’, so more the number of LFs, better the result. Every LF has its own latent accuracies which can be learned using overlap and conflicts with other LFs. So, if a LFs make correlated decision, without knowing if right or wrong, that LF will be assigned a higher weight. In the end, we will have a matrix will each labeling function assigned a weight. Usually, this step is iterated a few times to get improved results.

3. Training a Discriminative Model

Last part of the pipeline is the fastest one. The output of the generative model is a set of probabilistic training labels, we now want to use these to train our final Noise-aware discriminative model. We can use techniques like Logistic Regression, SVMs, LSTM at this stage. The discriminative model learns feature representation of our LFs and this makes it better able to generalize to unseen candidates. This increases recall significantly and gives the final output.

There is so much more to snorkel that cannot be covered in this blog. Snorkel derivatives like Snorkel Metal and Snorkel Drybell have gone further to improve both speed and accuracy of the result.

References:

  • Snorkel Website
  • GitHub Repository
  • Snorkel: Rapid Training Data Creation with Weak Supervision (VLDB 2018)
  • Data Programming: Creating Large Training Sets, Quickly (NeurIPS 2016)
  • Training Complex Models with Multi-Task Weak Supervision (AAAI 2019)
  • The Role of Massively Multi-Task and Weak Supervision in Software 2.0 (CIDR 2019)

entry.title: GSoC Final Report
entry.content:
This blog includes my work summary and my experience during Google Summer of Code’18 with Sugar Labs.

I am in the final phase of completing my project “Say no to Gtk2”, which includes The Porting of a few popular activities of sugarlabs from Gtk2 and GST0.10 to Gtk3 and GST1.0. It also included porting all activities to current standards followed by Sugar Labs to keep proper maintenance track of the activity. All students will now be able to use these activities again.

Activities

Here is the list of activities I worked on during GSoC period:

  • I Know My ABCs
  • Turtle Confusion
  • Pyeyes
  • Block Party
  • Adivinanz
  • Erikos
  • SocialCalc
  • Panorama
  • Feliz Navidad
  • Blocku
  • Ayni
  • Falabracman
  • Geotonky
  • Read sd comics
  • Cuidarme
  • I Can Read
  • Star Chart
  • Flip Sticks
  • Food Force
  • Arithmetic
  • Ajedrez
  • Follow Me Butia

Pull Request

Here is the list of pull requests I opened during GSoC period:

Merged

  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/falabracman-activity/pull/2
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/activity-turtle-confusion/pull/4
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/read-sd-comics/pull/6
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/cuidarme-activity/pull/2
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/GeoTonky/pull/1
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/blocku-1/pull/1
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/ayni-activity/pull/2
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/feliz-navidad-activity/pull/2
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/panorama/pull/5
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/spanish-guarani/pull/2
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/activity-erikos/pull/7
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/adivinanzas-activity/pull/
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/iknowmyabcs/pull/82
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/SocialCalc/pull/3
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/block-party-activity/pull/3
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/AEIOU/pull/11

Not merged yet:

  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/flipsticks/pull/3
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/foodforce2-activity/pull/1
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/followmeButia/pull/6
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/starchart/pull/6
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/i-can-read-activity/pull/8
  • https://github.com/sugarlabs/ajedrez-activity/pull/6

To Do

There are still some minor bugs to be fixed in the pull requests that are not merged yet, I am still adding fixes to them, will hold it until it’s in perfect shape. Releasing all these activities is also something we (I and mentor) decided to be done in post GSoC period.

GSoC Experience

It has been a great journey till here with Sugar Labs. I started to contribute to Sugar Labs in December 2017 and started making pull requests and taking part in weekly meetings. I started with sugarlabs website which involved CSS and js work, it was pretty comfortable with and then slowly moved towards working on sugar activities. I was completely alien to Gtk+ and Desktop Client development then but started getting hang of it a few days later. I have a total of 98 commits and 70 pull requests merged till date in Sugar Labs, a majority of them being Port to Gtk+3. I gained experience and some expertise in libraries like Gtk+, GStreamer, Cairo, Pango, Drawable etc.

Working with Sugar Labs

Sugar Labs is a great organization with some very talented developers, you always learn from others so much. A big shout out to Chihurumnaya Ibiam for being such a great mentor, it was a great experience working with him. James Cameron(quozl) has been a great mentor throughout, he has been kind enough take out time to explain me everything from scratch with great detail about things I had absolutely no idea about. Walter Bender has always been there for help and support. I would love to stay connected to Sugar Labs and keep on contributing to Sugar Labs

entry.title: GSoC Blog - Week 7
entry.content:
This is my eighth GSoC blog which tells work done this week.

Work Done This Week:

This Week I took a look on almost all the repositories that are in Gtk+ 2 and need a port to Gtk+ 3 and opened 16 new issues in various repositories. I also updated a repository where I keep a track of all Gtk+ 2, view updated list here.

This week I worked on following activities:

  • Agubrowser Activity
  • Dasher Activity
  • Block Party Activity
  • Star Chart Activity
  • SocialCalc Activity
  • Flip Sticks Activity

Agubrowser Activity

Minor Fixes to complete the port of this activity to Gtk+ 3.

Dasher Activity

Minor improvements.

Block Party Activity

Ported activity to Gtk+ 3, found a great tool while working on it, GtkIndpector, I suggest every GTK/Glib/Gnome enthusiast to check it out. It is meant to work like Chrome Developer tools and does it’s job very well. Faced a couple of issue and learned a lot while working on this acitivity. Adding a toolbar to this activiy was a bit of trouble becuase GtkDrawable was loosing it’s Key press event property. Quickfix for this issue issue is to change can_focus flag to True (verified using GtkInspector), but since it was originally designed to to keep away from the Sugar design, Quozl, Ibiam and I decided to keep it the way it is for now.

Star Chart Activity

Repeated Iterations are being made to this activity to take this to a point where it is ready for next release.

SocialCalc Activity

Fixes to complete the port of this activity to Gtk+ 3.

Flip Sticks Activity

This activity was a challenging activity to work on. All it’s code was written in Drawable, so first major work to port it Cairo, being a big activity this task was big in itself. Following this was porting to Gtk+ 3. Port to Gtk+ 3 was successful but Cairo part of this code is still buggy, Quozl has guided me to complete its work.

entry.title: GSoC Blog - Week 5
entry.content:
This is my sixth GSoC blog which tells work done this week.

Work Done This Week:

This week I worked on following activities:

  • Jigsaw Puzzle Activity
  • Star Chart Activity
  • AEIOU Activity
  • Turtle Confusion Activity
  • I Can Read Activity

Jigsaw Puzzle Activity

This is a jigsaw puzzle game activity on which some work was done by Zeeshan Khan who was doing this project last year. His work was half way through and took me couple of days to fix most of the errors that were logged. Latter I came across a issue, which after a hours of searching for a fix, prooved to be a bug in Cairo drawing itself. After discussion with Benjamin Berg from Gnome, who has been also been a contributor to Sugar Labs, found that only way to fix the problem is to refactor the code and avoid using window for each Jigsaw puzzle and use instead use Gtk.Drawing in place of it. This will lead to losing the functionality of mouse click used to drag and drop the jigsaw puzzle. After discussion with mentors, it was decided to defer this activity.

Star Chart Activity

Started my work on this activity and pushed some commits on Gtk3 branch on my fork.

AEIOU Acitivity

All work on this activity was completed and the pull request was merged in the master branch

Turtle Confusion Activity

Work on this Activity still continues. I am making all changes requested by James Cameron to make this commit mergeable.

I Can Read Activity

Spend another day on it, did get some success while fixing. Pull request is now closer to be merged.

  • Record Activity

To run this activity, I had to move from virtual box sugar live build, to Sugar build on ubuntu 17.10 installed on my laptop, this process made camera and microphone to be usable by the activity. On conversation with James, he asked me on continouos shot feature of it. I got confused later by his statement after reviewing to code and made a little change. Until further discussion, where he already fixed all issues and ported activity to GTK+ 3.

As mentioned earlier, this activity was similar to I Can Read Activity and others. It was relatively easier task to port this activity to GTK+ 3.

Pyeyes Activity
